[Question]
ok i have social anxiety i m actually quiet smart however when i m in social situation the anxiety is so much my brain go to mush like simple thing like counting money etc is so hard because my heart is beating through my ear i also dissociate ha anyone else experienced this phenomenon when i m by myself i can do all these task easily but in front of people literally become an invalid like it hilarious how people dumb down thing for me sad but all you can do is laugh

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming social anxiety can be, and it's not uncommon for people to experience physical symptoms like a racing heart and difficulty concentrating. Dissociation is also a common response to intense stress or anxiety. It's important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way, and there are steps you can take to manage your anxiety.

One technique that might help is deep breathing exercises. When you start feeling anxious, try taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help calm your nervous system and bring your focus back to the present moment.

Another strategy is to gradually expose yourself to social situations that make you anxious. Start with smaller, more manageable interactions, and gradually work your way up to larger gatherings. It's also helpful to have a support system in place, whether it's a trusted friend or family member who can provide encouragement and understanding.

Additionally, practicing self-care activities can help reduce overall stress levels. This could include things like regular exercise, getting enough sleep, eating a balanced diet, and engaging in hobbies or activities that bring you joy.

Remember, managing social anxiety takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories. If your anxiety continues to significantly impact your daily life, it may be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health therapist who can provide personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
for the past year and a half i ve had constant tiredness fatigue and just haven t felt like myself i used to be pretty active always working on project excited about life for the last year and a half i just feel like a shell of myself tired and meh i m also hungry constantly i ve seen my doctor and a few different specialist and had plenty of blood work done including thyroid and everything ha been normal no sleep apnea no anemia no lyme my doc said we have essentially ruled out most if not all straight up medical cause of fatigue beyond the possibility i m just not getting good sleep due to underlying stress or anxiety hard for me to tell how well i m sleeping not waking up refreshed but i m in bed for hr a night i ve begun to wonder if i m simply depressed since everything else ha kind of been ruled out i don t feel very sad and i don t feel hopeless i don t lack the motivation to do all the thing i love i just feel too tired or lazy to do them but i really want to be my old self again if i could snap my finger and have my energy back i d do it in a heartbeat how do i know if i m depressed

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how frustrating it is to feel like you're not yourself and constantly tired. It's great that you've already seen your doctor and had blood work done, but it seems like there might still be an underlying cause for your fatigue.

Considering your symptoms, it's possible that you could be experiencing depression, even if you don't feel sad or hopeless. Depression can manifest in various ways, and feeling tired or lazy is a common symptom. It's important to remember that depression can coexist with other conditions, such as anxiety or stress, which can impact your energy levels.

To determine if you're depressed, it might be helpful to explore your thoughts and emotions further. Have you noticed any changes in your mood or appetite recently? Have you experienced any negative thoughts or self-critical thoughts? Additionally, it could be beneficial to keep a journal to track your daily activities, sleep patterns, and any significant changes in your energy levels.

If you're unsure about your mental health, it might be worth considering reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide a comprehensive evaluation and guide you through this process. They can help determine if you're experiencing depression and provide appropriate treatment options.

In the meantime, there are some lifestyle changes you can try to improve your energy levels. Regular exercise, even if it's just a short walk each day, can help boost your mood and increase your energy. Additionally, practicing stress management techniques like deep breathing exercises, meditation, or mindfulness can help reduce anxiety and promote better sleep.

Remember, it's important to be patient with yourself as you navigate through this process. You deserve to feel better and regain your energy.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i live in my bedroom weekend burn by fast with me playing video game i bought a new car but lack will to learn how to get comfortable with it i want to do thing but i don t want to drive myself to these place in fear of crashing into something and my job is easy and amazing pay but somehow i find a way to disdain it and my coworkers i want to start dating again but all the sudden i ve become embarrassed of who i am i feel like i m boring and not really interesting to talk to my coworkers like to find my insecurity and turn it into a joke for everyone and i haven t done anything to them i m just there i feel like i m losing my grip on reality sometimes and just want to end it forever and if i did nothing of value would be lost and nobody would really care i m afraid of change yet i want it so much at the same time i just wish i were a more outgoing person who doesn t let other s word get to me

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming and frustrating it can be to feel this way. It's important to remember that you're not alone in experiencing these emotions, and there are steps you can take to address them.

Firstly, it might be helpful to start by acknowledging and accepting your feelings. It's okay to feel fear and embarrassment, but it's also important to recognize that these emotions don't define who you are as a person. Remind yourself that everyone has insecurities and goes through ups and downs in their lives.

Next, consider setting small, achievable goals for yourself. For example, if you want to start dating again, you could begin by taking a few minutes each day to practice self-care and boost your confidence. This could involve engaging in activities you enjoy, such as exercising, reading, or spending time in nature.

Additionally, it might be beneficial to challenge any negative thoughts or beliefs you have about yourself. Whenever you catch yourself thinking negatively, try to counter those thoughts with positive affirmations or evidence of your worthiness and interesting qualities.

In terms of learning to drive, you could start by researching local driving schools or classes that offer beginner-friendly programs. Taking small steps towards acquiring this skill can help alleviate some of your fears and gradually build your confidence behind the wheel.

Regarding your coworkers, it's important to remember that their behavior is a reflection of their own insecurities and issues, rather than a reflection of your worth as a person. If their jokes bother you, consider having an open and honest conversation with them about how their comments affect you. You might find that they are unaware of the impact their words have on you, and they may be willing to make a change.

Lastly, if you continue to struggle with these feelings of wanting to end your life, it's crucial to seek professional help from a mental health expert who can provide you with the appropriate support and guidance.

Remember, change takes time and effort, but with patience and self-compassion, you can work towards becoming the outgoing and confident person you aspire to be.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming and challenging your situation is. It's important to acknowledge that you're not alone in feeling this way. You've been through a lot, and it's understandable that you're feeling mentally exhausted and hopeless.

Firstly, I want to assure you that your feelings are valid, and it's okay to feel this way. You're not crazy for seeking help or expressing your struggles. It takes a lot of courage to reach out, and I commend you for taking this step.

Given the complexities of your situation, it might be helpful to consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide you with the guidance and support you need. They can help you navigate through your challenges, develop coping strategies, and explore potential treatment options for your OCD.

In the meantime, there are some things you can try on your own. One approach is to practice self-care and prioritize your well-being. This could involve engaging in activities that bring you joy or relaxation, such as listening to music, going for walks in nature, practicing mindfulness or meditation, or pursuing hobbies that interest you.

Additionally, it might be beneficial to establish a support system, even if it's virtual. Connecting with others who have similar experiences or interests can help you feel less alone and provide a sense of belonging. Online communities or forums focused on mental health, hobbies, or shared interests can be great places to start.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. You deserve happiness and fulfillment in your life, and with the right support and guidance, it's possible to find them.

Please know that I'm here for you, and I genuinely care about your well-being. You don't have to face this alone, and there is hope for a brighter future.

hey friend i come asking question about workplace anxiety i m 9 and work retail i realize that this is a job with low stake and that whatever fear i have about making mistake are rather silly given the nature of the job however i ve worked myself up because i worked an event this evening and in my eye it wa just a series of unfortunate event first i show up early but still later than my coworker who i wa working with for the event he wa talking to our bos second i wa underdressed he looked so sharp granted i am 9 and he is almost a full decade older than me with the life experience to really comprehend dress code it wa rather unspecified and unclear so i m trying not to beat myself up too much about it i ran home super quickly and grabbed some nicer shoe and a jacket but it still wasn t great third my bos gave u her number to text or to call if we needed any help i texted her first and then she asked if i would call her because she wa on the road make sense but i feel i made a mistake texting her in the first place fourth fifth sixth and so on i worry that throughout the entire evening i wad screwing up and ended up losing the store a ton of money i m so upset about everything that happened and being liked by my bos that i wa cry and now i can t sleep please oh please i beg of y all how do i get over this it s making my day really difficult and i don t want this to follow me into the future when if i have a job much more demanding and serious if i mess up it s eating me up and i can t take it thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult it can be to deal with workplace anxiety, especially when it feels like you're constantly making mistakes and worrying about the consequences. It's important to remember that everyone makes mistakes, and it's natural to feel upset when things don't go as planned. However, it's not helpful to beat yourself up over these situations. Instead, try to focus on what you can control and how you can learn from these experiences.

First, it might be helpful to remind yourself that the nature of your job is relatively low-stakes, and the fear of making mistakes is probably not warranted given the circumstances. It's okay to make mistakes and learn from them.

Regarding the dress code, it sounds like there was some confusion about what was expected. While it's understandable that you wanted to present yourself well, it's important to remember that appearances don't always determine success or competence. Your value as an employee goes beyond what you wear.

The situation with your coworker and your boss is also worth considering. It seems like there was some miscommunication, and you ended up feeling like you were constantly screwing up. However, it's important to recognize that these interactions may not accurately reflect your abilities or the value you bring to the company.

It's understandable that you're feeling upset and worried about how this will affect your future job prospects. However, it's important to separate these feelings from reality. Mistakes are a normal part of life, and they don't define your worth as a person or an employee. Instead of dwelling on what happened, focus on what you can do differently in the future to prevent similar situations.

In terms of coping with your anxiety, it might be helpful to practice self-compassion. Remind yourself that everyone makes mistakes, and it's okay to feel upset about it. However, try not to dwell on negative thoughts or assumptions about yourself. Instead, challenge those thoughts by reminding yourself of your strengths and accomplishments.

Additionally, consider finding healthy ways to manage your anxiety. This could include engaging in activities that help you relax, such as exercise, meditation, or hobbies. It might also be beneficial to talk to someone you trust about what you're going through, whether it's a friend, family member, or even a counselor.

Remember, it's important to give yourself credit for the effort you're putting into improving your situation. You're not alone in this, and there are resources available to help you navigate through these challenges.

[Question]
for the past few day i ve been dealing with extreme bout of anxiety i feel anxious all day nausea all day and i cant seem to stop thinking about negative thought i ve been dealing with a lot of ups and down regarding school and romantic relationship i keep skipping school because my anxiety is way too high i dont know how to calm it down i want to see a psychologist but right now it very hard to get to see one so i ll need all any advice you have thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming it can be to deal with extreme anxiety, especially when it's affecting your daily life and relationships. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to help manage your anxiety.

First, try practicing deep breathing exercises whenever you feel anxious. Taking slow, deep breaths can help activate your body's relaxation response and calm your mind. You can also try progressive muscle relaxation, where you tense and relax different muscle groups in your body to release tension.

Additionally, it might be helpful to challenge negative thoughts that contribute to your anxiety. Ask yourself if there is evidence to support these thoughts or if they are based on assumptions. Try replacing them with more realistic and positive thoughts.

In terms of school and romantic relationships, it might be beneficial to communicate openly with those involved. Let them know about your struggles with anxiety and how it's impacting you. They may be able to offer support or accommodations that can help alleviate some of the stress.

If you find it difficult to see a psychologist right now, consider exploring self-help resources such as books or online articles on anxiety management techniques. While they may not replace professional help, they can provide additional guidance and support.

Remember, everyone's journey with anxiety is unique, so it's important to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself as you navigate through this challenging time, and don't hesitate to reach out for professional help when you feel ready.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 I'm sorry to hear that you've been going through such a difficult time, and I can understand how frustrating it is to be prescribed a medication that didn't help, and to feel like no one cared about your situation. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are resources available to help you navigate through this challenging period.

One suggestion I have is to consider reaching out to a support group or therapist who can provide a safe space for you to express your feelings and experiences. They can help you process the emotions you're experiencing and provide guidance on how to cope with the side effects of the medication. Additionally, they may be able to offer alternative treatment options or suggest lifestyle changes that could improve your overall well-being.

Another suggestion is to focus on self-care activities that bring you joy and relaxation. This could include engaging in hobbies, spending time in nature, practicing mindfulness or meditation, or connecting with loved ones. Taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally can help improve your overall mood and resilience.

Lastly, it might be helpful to keep a journal where you can document your thoughts and feelings. Writing down your experiences can provide a sense of release and allow you to reflect on your journey. You can also use this as an opportunity to set goals for yourself and identify steps you can take towards improving your situation.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to ask for help along the way. You deserve support and understanding, and I hope that you find the resources and guidance you need to move forward.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult it is for you to articulate your feelings and thoughts, and it's clear that you're dealing with a complex and deeply personal issue. It takes a lot of courage to share this with someone, and I appreciate your openness.

Based on what you've shared, it seems like you're struggling with a sense of identity and control over your own life. You mentioned feeling like everything is a fever dream, and that you're being carried by something else that you don't really have control over. This can be incredibly overwhelming and lead to feelings of sadness, happiness, suicidal thoughts, and manic optimism.

It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are people who can help you navigate through these challenges. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some suggestions that might be helpful for you.

Firstly, it might be beneficial to explore therapy or counseling options. A therapist can provide a safe space for you to express your thoughts and emotions, and they can help you gain insight into the underlying causes of your feelings. They can also provide guidance and support as you work towards finding a sense of control and understanding in your life.

Additionally, consider reaching out to support groups or communities where you can connect with others who may have similar experiences. Sharing your story with people who can relate to what you're going through can be incredibly validating and comforting.

In terms of managing your thoughts and emotions, practicing self-care is crucial. This could involve engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies, exercise, or spending time in nature. Taking care of your physical health by getting enough sleep, eating well, and avoiding excessive substance use can also contribute to your overall well-being.

Remember, healing takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and acknowledge that you're doing the best you can. You deserve love, happiness, and fulfilling relationships, and with the right support and guidance, it's possible to find them.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Additionally, setting realistic goals for yourself can help combat the feeling of being a burden. Start small and focus on achievable tasks that bring you joy or fulfillment. Celebrate each accomplishment, no matter how small, as it can help boost your self-esteem and motivation.

Lastly, remember that change takes time and effort. Be patient with yourself throughout this process and practice self-compassion. Surround yourself with supportive friends and family members who can offer encouragement and understanding.

i tried to od on tylenol and took like 0 pill ended up tripping ball then throwing up and being miserable for the rest of the night now i have some sort of phobia in which i can not even think about taking pill without getting extremely nauseous anyone know how to overcome this new fear is there a better subreddit to ask this question

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm sorry to hear that you've been experiencing such a distressing reaction to Tylenol. It's understandable that this has created a fear and discomfort around taking medication. While I'm not an expert, I can offer some suggestions that might help you overcome this fear.

1. Gradual exposure: Start by taking small, manageable steps towards taking your medication. Begin with a very small dose and gradually increase it over time. This approach allows you to build up your tolerance and confidence in taking the medication.

2. Relaxation techniques: Practice deep breathing exercises or other relaxation techniques to help calm your mind and body before taking your medication. This can help reduce anxiety and make the experience more manageable.

3. Seek support: Consider talking to someone you trust about your fears and concerns. They may be able to provide emotional support and help you find additional coping strategies.

4. Educate yourself: Learn more about the potential benefits of your medication and how it works in your body. Understanding the science behind the medication can help alleviate some of your fears and concerns.

5. Find a supportive community: While Reddit can be a valuable source of information, it's important to remember that online communities may not always provide the most personalized or accurate advice. If you're struggling to overcome your fear, consider seeking guidance from a healthcare professional or a mental health therapist who can provide tailored support and strategies for you.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it may take time to overcome this fear. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how you're feeling. It's common to experience a sense of unease or discomfort after making significant changes in your life, especially when they involve leaving a toxic work environment and starting a new job. It's natural to feel a bit out of control and longing for something more, especially when everything feels chaotic and out of place.

One suggestion I have is to try practicing mindfulness techniques. Mindfulness involves paying attention to the present moment without judgment. This can help you ground yourself and create a sense of calmness. You can start by simply focusing on your breath or engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as going for a walk in nature or listening to soothing music.

Another idea is to explore your feelings further by journaling or talking to someone you trust about what you're experiencing. Sometimes, putting our thoughts and emotions into words can help us gain clarity and understanding. Additionally, consider seeking support from a therapist who can provide guidance tailored to your specific situation.

Remember, it's okay to feel this way and it's normal to have these feelings after going through significant changes. Give yourself time and patience as you navigate through this period of adjustment.

 I'm sorry to hear that you've been experiencing such distressing symptoms after taking the gummies. It's understandable that you're feeling concerned about your mental health and well-being. You mentioned that you've been experiencing occasional bad thoughts, and it's concerning that you're worried about doing something bad. It's crucial to address these thoughts and seek professional help if they persist or worsen. [Question]
i have been suffering from an eating disorder anorexia anorexia nervosa since i wa yo i m in my early 0 now about a month ago i had an issue with my chinese takeout that heighten not only my ed but my anxiety level too i constantly fear that everything i eat will cause stomach ache or make me sick so i m cautious to eat anything anymore i have slowly been on the road to recovery with my ed so this made me take step back rather than moving forward it ha also caused me to lose sleep at night and when i do end up sleeping i wake up with awful anxiety my anxiety ha been overwhelming because a day doe not go by where i m not excessively panicking i can t even go out of my house without breaking down it is so bad that i only ever feel safe in my own room i feel like i m trapped in this on going cycle with no kind of exit i am desperate to find a solution to my problem but therapy ha not worked for me nor medication i have no idea what i need to do to better my food anxiety and general anxiety i do my absolute best to not think about it all of my issue but it s so damn hard when my body say otherwise ha anyone suffered from this did you find anything that helped alleviate your anxiety or ed any helpful advice is welcome

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult it is to deal with both eating disorders and anxiety. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this struggle, and there are steps you can take to improve your situation.

Firstly, it might be helpful to try gradually exposing yourself to foods that make you anxious or cause discomfort. Start with small portions and slowly increase the amount over time. This can help desensitize your body and mind to the fear of eating certain foods.

Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation could be beneficial for managing your anxiety. These techniques can help calm your mind and body, allowing you to feel more grounded and present in the moment.

It may also be worth exploring cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) specifically tailored to addressing food anxiety and eating disorders. CBT focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns and behaviors associated with these issues. A therapist trained in CBT can guide you through this process and provide you with effective coping strategies.

In addition to therapy, consider reaching out to support groups or online communities where you can connect with others who have experienced similar challenges. Sharing your story and hearing from others who have overcome their own struggles can provide validation and encouragement.

I hope these suggestions offer some guidance and support as you navigate your way towards healing.

countless hurtful thing and done endless physical damage to the house living with her is very stressful on top of all this my grandpa just died tonight i got a call from my brother out of the blue i Regarding your school situation, it might be helpful to have an open conversation with your academic advisor or professors about your struggles. They may be able to offer support, accommodations, or resources that could help you get back on track.

When it comes to your jobs, it's understandable that you feel pessimistic and frustrated. However, it's important to remember that your experiences at work do not define your worth as a person. Consider discussing your concerns with your supervisors or HR department, as they may be able to provide guidance or assistance. Additionally, focusing on your strengths and past experiences can help you maintain a sense of self-worth and confidence in your abilities.

Lastly, I encourage you to practice self-care and prioritize your mental health. This could include engaging in activities that bring you joy, such as hobbies or exercise. Additionally, consider setting small, achievable goals for yourself each day to help build momentum and motivation.

Remember, it takes time and effort to overcome depression, but with the right support and strategies, it is possible to find some contentment and happiness in your life.

[Question]
on the surface i can think of a lot of reason feeling ashamed about needing med worrying about side effect forgetting about them etc but at the end of the day i can t say exactly why i just know i don t want to take my med at the same time i know i need them i know that without them i simple task like showering and doing dish feel impossible i ll fall behind on my schoolwork isolated myself and sleep hour a day i know they work for me and that i ve felt much better when i wa taking them regularly but dang it i just don t want to take them one day i just ignored my alarm to take them and then i ve kept doing it now i take them so sporadically that they can t be doing much they re an ssri and mood stabilizer so they need to build up in your system and such part of me think maybe i just hate the daily reminder that i m not ok like i think that maybe if i ignore it for long enough i ll forget that i feel that way but even knowing that may be a part of it it doesn t feel like that s all there is to it and i don t know what to do about it mostly i m just wondering if anyone else feel like this too and if you do do you know why you feel that way and what may have helped you get back on track with taking them regularly i ve talked to my therapist and friend but i haven t been able to really figure out the full reason i feel this way or how to get back to taking them regularly if you ve dealt with this before or think you may understand why this resistance to taking med is happening i d appreciate hearing some potential reason or way to improve this of course everyone s mental health is unique so i may not relate to someone else s reason but i would still really appreciate hearing any potential one so i can understand my feeling about this a bit better

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how challenging it can be to take medication regularly, especially when you're feeling ashamed or forgetful. It's important to remember that these feelings are common among individuals taking medication for mental health conditions. The fact that you recognize the benefits of the medication and have felt better when taking them regularly shows your self-awareness and willingness to improve your well-being.

One possible reason for this resistance could be the daily reminder that you're not okay. It's natural to want to forget or ignore those feelings, as they can be overwhelming. However, it's crucial to acknowledge these feelings and understand that they are part of your journey towards healing. You might find it helpful to explore the root cause of this resistance with a therapist or counselor who can provide guidance tailored to your specific situation.

In addition to therapy, there are some strategies you can try on your own to help improve medication adherence. Setting reminders on your phone or calendar can help you remember to take your medication at consistent times. Creating a routine around medication-taking, such as associating it with a specific activity or reward, can also make it feel more manageable.

It's also important to communicate openly with your healthcare provider about your concerns and challenges with medication adherence. They may be able to suggest alternative dosing schedules or adjust your treatment plan accordingly. Remember, your healthcare provider is there to support you and work collaboratively towards your mental well-being.

Lastly, consider reaching out to support groups or online communities where individuals facing similar challenges share their experiences and coping strategies. Connecting with others who have gone through similar struggles can provide validation and inspiration.

Keep in mind that everyone's experience is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. Be patient with yourself as you navigate this process and remember that you deserve support and understanding throughout your journey towards better mental health.

so i wa just working a completely normal day in fact i felt pretty good i work at a goodwill so it s relatively social but i can handle it cause honestly every person that enters that store is fantastically polite and friendly but for some reason half way through my shift i begin getting light head i assumed it wa my tight hat or my new prescription glass so i took those off and got back to work and for a little bit actually helped but it got worse and worse my hand were shaky and i wa super light headed bless my coworkers cause i mentioned i wasn t feeling great and my manager let me have a break despite not requiring one due to shirt shift one of my coworkers actually spent a dollar to get me a snack and i wa improving i didn t wan na leave these lovely people short staffed a i wa the only product handler closing so i tried getting back on the floor and instantly i wa back in it and again bless my manager cause she suggested it wa fine and i could go home i got in my car and instantly my face felt numb by the time i wa home a relatively short drive my chest wa super numb too im i ve only ever had this feeling once before and i wa wondering if this is what a standard panic attack feel like how do i bring this up with my dad in order to get this figured out sorry if this wa long it actually helped a good bit in getting me relaxed just writing this

 I understand how overwhelming it can be to experience such a sudden change in your physical and mental well-being. It's important to acknowledge your feelings and take care of yourself. It's crucial to address this issue with your doctor to determine the underlying cause and explore potential treatment options. am in talk with a therapy at a church in a city thanks a lot

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand your concerns and the emotional challenges you're facing. It's important to acknowledge that your past experiences have shaped your current feelings and behaviors. You've shown resilience in many aspects of your life, and it's great that you're seeking therapy to help you navigate these emotions.

In terms of your fear of judgment from others, it's natural to feel apprehensive about being in a relationship with someone who isn't brown or having a relationship in a predominantly white neighborhood. However, it's crucial to remember that people's reactions are often influenced by their own biases and experiences. You deserve to be loved and accepted for who you are, regardless of external judgments.

Your hyper-independence can be both a strength and a challenge. While it's important to take care of yourself and not rely on others excessively, it's also essential to build healthy relationships and seek support when needed. Remember that asking for help doesn't make you weak; it shows strength and vulnerability.

Your childhood experiences have undoubtedly had a significant impact on your current emotional state. It's understandable that you've developed a fear of falling back into old patterns and being rejected by others. However, with therapy, you can work on identifying and challenging these fears, developing coping mechanisms, and building healthier relationships.

Regarding your intimacy issues, it's not uncommon for individuals to struggle with feeling comfortable in physical intimacy. This could be related to past trauma or a fear of vulnerability. Exploring these issues with a therapist can help you gain insight into the root causes and develop strategies to overcome them.

Lastly, your independent nature has allowed you to stand up for yourself and make decisions based on your own values. However, it's important to strike a balance between independence and seeking support from others. Building a strong support system can provide you with the emotional safety and companionship you're looking for.

Remember, therapy is a collaborative process, and your therapist will work with you to address your specific concerns and develop personalized strategies for growth and healing.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way, and I want you to know that there is hope for you. It takes a lot of strength to reach out and share your thoughts with someone, so I commend you for that.

You mentioned that you've had happy days but haven't been able to appreciate them, and that you're hyper-focused on the bad things in your life. This is a common experience for many people who are feeling depressed or suicidal. It's important to remember that these feelings are not your fault, and they don't define who you are as a person.

You also mentioned that you're trying to distance yourself from others because you don't want them to be affected by your decision. While it's understandable that you want to protect your loved ones, it's important to remember that they care about you and want to help you through this difficult time. Regarding your appearance, it's common for individuals experiencing depression to have negative thoughts about themselves. i m and i ve wished i wa dead for the last two year of my life i pushed away all of my friend who could understand what i m going through i m failing all my class because all of my motivation and hope is drained i don t feel like i can tell anyone what i m really going through i had all the making of a perfect childhood i wa smart i had friend and i had a good family with enough money to live in a nice suburban neighborhood i threw all of it away because suddenly i didn t feel wanted any longer i don t know what to do anymore the thing ive used to cope are slowly being taken away in the hope my grade will rise i ve become emotionally numb to everything around me i don t think i ll ever find love because of how quiet and secluded i ve become i ve stopped trying to make thing better in my life i just needed to get some of this out so thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm sorry to hear that you've been feeling this way for the past two years. It sounds like you've been through a lot and it's understandable that you've pushed away your friends and lost motivation. You mentioned that you used to have a good childhood, but for some reason, you started feeling unwanted and unloved. This has led to emotional numbness and a feeling that you won't be able to find love again.

It's important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way, and there are steps you can take to start healing and finding happiness again. One suggestion is to reach out to one or two of your former friends who you feel comfortable talking to. They may not understand everything you're going through, but having someone to confide in can be helpful. Additionally, consider seeking professional help from a therapist who can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific situation.

In therapy, you can explore the underlying reasons behind your feelings of worthlessness and unloveliness. Sometimes, past experiences or unresolved issues can contribute to these emotions. By addressing these underlying factors, you may be able to gain a better understanding of yourself and work towards healing.

While it may seem daunting at first, try to reintroduce small acts of self-care into your life. This could include activities that bring you joy or relaxation, such as listening to music, going for walks, practicing mindfulness or meditation, or engaging in hobbies you used to enjoy. These small steps can help rekindle your sense of self-worth and hope.

Lastly, remember that change takes time and effort. Be patient with yourself as you navigate through this difficult period. You deserve happiness and love, and with the right support and tools, it is possible to find them again.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m f currently on a work trip with a few of my coworkers most of whom i ve known for year but haven t seen in person since covid started i m decently close with one person in particular and the rest i just have a normal professional relationship with last night everyone went out to celebrate a big milestone during the trip and had a great time i wa definitely pretty drunk by the end of the night and getting home is a little hazy but i woke up with good memory of the night before and wasn t concerned that anything had happened anyways no one had texted me this morning and i wasn t sure what the plan for the day wa so i reached out to the coworker i m closer with and asked what she wa up to she said she wa going to breakfast with another person on the trip and that i could come which i agreed to but then she texted and said they were actually leaving right now for breakfast and that we could meet up later this seemed odd to me since we re all in the same hotel and i could have been ready to head out whenever but it felt like she didn t want me to come i think i m reading into it a bit too much but now i m freaking out worried that i did something wrong last night and that s the reason i m not being invited along today i don t really have a track record of doing thing out of character while drunk though so i m just really confused and anxious tldr got drunk with coworkers who i haven t seen in a while and now it feel like no one want to hang out with me

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how confusing and anxiety-inducing this situation is for you. It's natural to feel concerned when you wake up and realize that something might have happened the night before, especially if you've had a lot to drink. However, it's important to remember that people can have different interpretations of what constitutes "having a good time" and it's possible that your coworkers simply wanted to start their day without you.

You mentioned that you have a normal professional relationship with most of your coworkers, so it's unlikely that anything you did during the celebration would have caused them to exclude you from their plans. It's also worth considering that they might have had other reasons for leaving earlier than planned, such as personal commitments or other plans.

To alleviate your anxiety, try focusing on the things you can control in this situation. You can reach out to the coworker you're closer to and express your confusion about why they didn't invite you to breakfast. However, it's important to approach the conversation with an open mind and avoid jumping to conclusions. You might find that there was a misunderstanding or miscommunication that can be easily resolved.

In the meantime, try to engage in activities that make you feel good and help you relax. This could include going for a walk, practicing deep breathing exercises, or engaging in a hobby you enjoy. Remember, it's normal to feel a little down or anxious after a night of heavy drinking, but these feelings should pass with time.

If you continue to feel overwhelmed by these emotions, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide you with additional guidance and support. They can help you explore any underlying issues that may be contributing to your anxiety and develop coping strategies tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

im seriously so stuck i developed a horrible case of health anxiety and constantly think something is wrong with my brain or heart i ve been to the er twice now with everything coming back normal i feel bed ridden most day if im up and moving around for too long i feel extremely dizzy due to my tension headache i have high blood pressure and am on medication but i constantly think it s hurting my heart im only year old and i shouldn t be this concerned about my health i m so over feeling this way and every day get worse and worse i feel like i can t do anything but lay down i get sharp pain along my chest due to costochondritis and im always thinking it s the end my breathing is always fine and my heart never beat super rapidly so that make me feel better but the dizziness is unbearable i tried antidepressant and all they did wa make my anxiety worse and my heart beat abnormally fast anytime i stood up my doctor took me off of them and is more focused on my blood pressure im so scared of dying and i m so sick of feeling like this

It's important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way, and there are steps you can take to manage your health anxiety and improve your overall well-being.

Firstly, it might be helpful to explore the root cause of your health anxiety. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some general suggestions. Consider keeping a journal to track your thoughts and feelings throughout the day. This can help you identify any patterns or triggers that contribute to your anxiety. Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation may help alleviate some of the dizziness and overall discomfort you're experiencing.

Regarding your medication, it's crucial to communicate openly with your doctor about your concerns. They may be able to adjust your dosage or suggest alternative treatments that could address both your high blood pressure and anxiety. Remember, it's essential to work closely with a healthcare professional who can provide personalized guidance based on your specific situation.

While it's understandable that you're feeling scared and concerned about your health, it's important to focus on building a support system around you. Surround yourself with understanding friends or family members who can offer emotional support during this challenging time. Additionally, consider seeking out online communities or support groups where you can connect with others who may be experiencing similar health anxiety symptoms.

Lastly, if your symptoms persist or worsen, it's important to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide you with the appropriate care and guidance. They can help you develop coping strategies tailored to your needs and work towards managing your health anxiety effectively.

Remember, you deserve to feel better and live a fulfilling life. Don't hesitate to seek the help and support you need to overcome this challenging period.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm sorry to hear that you've been struggling with depression for a long time and that it has affected your relationships and led to self-harming thoughts. It's understandable that you're tired of fighting and want to find peace. However, it's important to remember that there is hope for healing and finding joy in life again.

One suggestion I have is to consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide you with the guidance and support you need. They can help you explore the underlying causes of your depression and develop coping strategies to manage your symptoms. Additionally, they can work with you to create a safety plan that includes steps to prevent self-harm and ensure your safety.

Another suggestion is to try engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. This could be anything from hobbies, exercise, creative outlets, or spending time in nature. These activities can help distract your mind from negative thoughts and provide a sense of purpose and satisfaction.

It's also important to surround yourself with a supportive network of friends and family. While it may not always feel like it, they care about you and want to help you through this difficult time. Consider opening up to them about what you're going through and let them offer their support and understanding.

Lastly, remember that healing takes time and patience. It's okay to have ups and downs along the way, but with the right support and perseverance, it is possible to find happiness and overcome the challenges you're facing.

[Question]
i m not sure if i have anxiety or adhd or im just introverted and procrastinating lol i started biting my nail since i wa a kid i tried hard to get rid of this habit but it not something i can control i put on nail polish usually but once it fall ill start biting them or fixing them with nail clipper a little bit of unsmoothness on my nail will bother me a lot and ill just sit there and keep fixing it for hour straight instead of doing any work literally every 0 min i would find somewhere bothering me on my nail i also overthink a lot it might be influenced by my mom who kept telling me that others might think negatively about me bc of any barely noticeable detail about what i do how i look so now i will just replay some scenario in my head hundred of time feel bad about myself and had to take deep breath say to myself it ok out loud or make some sudden noise to make my mind jump out of that vicious loop recently i feel that my attention span is getting even shorter i will sit down for work and get distracted after min and start watching youtube video for hour i notice myself doing that and i would think maybe i should go back to work but the other part of my mind is like numb and fail to take any action to the point that im only able to focus for a long time under pressure like a day before meeting or exam idk if it is just bad work ethic procrastination introversion or i should get a check up for anxiety adhd like i heard other ppl relate to me on point amp so idk if it just some common problem that i can just work it out either way can anyone give me any advice on whether to get a diagnosis or smth i could do on my own to mitigate these behavior thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand that you're feeling uncertain about whether you have anxiety, ADHD, or if it's just your introverted nature and procrastination. It's important to remember that everyone's experiences are unique, and it might be helpful to explore these symptoms further.

To start, let's focus on your nail biting habit. While it's understandable that you've tried to get rid of it, it seems like something you can't fully control. Instead of trying to completely eliminate the habit, you could try finding alternative ways to cope with stress or boredom. For example, you could try keeping your hands busy with activities like knitting, painting, or playing an instrument. Additionally, you mentioned that putting on nail polish usually helps, so perhaps you could try incorporating that into your routine as a reminder to stop biting.

Regarding your attention span, it's common for individuals to struggle with staying focused, especially when they're feeling overwhelmed or distracted. One technique you could try is breaking down your tasks into smaller, manageable chunks. By focusing on one task at a time, you may find it easier to maintain your attention and make progress. Additionally, creating a structured schedule and setting specific goals for yourself can help you stay motivated and on track.

You mentioned that you overthink a lot and tend to replay scenarios in your head, which can lead to feelings of self-doubt and negativity. One strategy that might be helpful is practicing mindfulness. Mindfulness involves paying attention to the present moment without judgment. You can start by taking deep breaths and bringing your awareness to your senses - what you see, hear, smell, taste, and touch. This practice can help redirect your thoughts away from negative self-talk and bring you back to the present moment.

While it's understandable that you're considering a diagnosis, it's important to remember that only a qualified mental health professional can provide an accurate assessment. However, if you feel that your symptoms are significantly impacting your daily life and functioning, it may be worth exploring further. They can provide you with a comprehensive evaluation and offer guidance on potential treatment options.

In the meantime, you can also try some self-help resources such as books or online articles that discuss anxiety, ADHD, and procrastination. These resources may provide additional insights and strategies that could be beneficial for you.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. You've already shown resilience by recognizing your struggles and seeking advice. Keep exploring different techniques and strategies until you find what works best for you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i have these bad episode of anxiety that last for day where i m constantly dissociated and whenever i try to sleep i wake up almost every hour with my body completely numb and my vision is like zoomed out and everything is super disoriented and weird i m so tired but i can t sleep and it keep me up all night and i m so exhausted i just want at least one good night rest but i can t even get that i feel like anxiety and dissociation are constantly kicking me around and i can never catch a break in life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming and exhausting it can be to experience these episodes of anxiety and dissociation, especially when they interfere with your ability to sleep. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to help manage these symptoms.

One suggestion is to establish a consistent sleep routine. Going to bed and waking up at the same time every day, even on weekends, can help regulate your body's internal clock and improve the quality of your sleep. Additionally, creating a relaxing bedtime routine, such as reading a book or taking a warm bath, can signal to your body that it's time to wind down and prepare for sleep.

Another strategy you might find helpful is practicing relaxation techniques before bed. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or guided imagery can all help calm your mind and body, making it easier to fall asleep and stay asleep. You could also try incorporating these techniques into your daily routine, as they can help reduce overall anxiety levels throughout the day.

It's worth mentioning that while these suggestions may be beneficial for some individuals, they may not address the root causes of your anxiety and dissociation. If you feel that these symptoms are significantly impacting your daily life and well-being, it may be worth considering reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support. They can work with you to explore potential underlying factors contributing to your symptoms and develop a treatment plan tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, you deserve to have a good night's rest, and there are resources available to help you achieve that. Take care of yourself and don't hesitate to seek the help you need.

[Question]
i have no idea if this is anxiety but this is the reason why im asking lately i ve been extremely overthinking the most smallest thing and worrying about the most thing that i ve been overthinking about this happens throughout the day and disrupts my life it s even disrupting me whilst i m typing i worry and overthink thing that could cause health problem but the thing are sooo small i ve wasted so many food thinking this could be dangerous i know it sound stupid because i can barely even explain it it s taking a toll on me but i know that the other day when i got outside the house i wasn t thinking about it and i felt better but then when i got back to the house and started up again i just know i keep overthinking and worrying about the smallest thing health related i can t tell you the amount of time that i ve been back and forth to the doctor this year and last year worrying myself

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming it can be to constantly worry about the smallest things, especially when they seem to disrupt your daily life. It's important to remember that you're not alone in experiencing this, and there are steps you can take to manage your anxiety.

Firstly, it might be helpful to identify any patterns or triggers that contribute to your overthinking and worrying. Keeping a journal or making a list of the situations or thoughts that tend to trigger these feelings could provide some insight into what exactly is causing your anxiety.

Once you have identified these triggers, you can start implementing strategies to cope with them. One technique is called "thought stopping," where you mentally say "stop" when you catch yourself overthinking or worrying about something. This can help break the cycle of anxious thoughts.

Another approach is practicing mindfulness or meditation. These techniques can help you become more aware of your thoughts and emotions without judgment, allowing you to let go of some of the excessive worrying.

Additionally, engaging in regular physical activity, such as walking or yoga, can also be beneficial for managing anxiety. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters.

Lastly, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide guidance tailored specifically to your situation. They can offer additional coping mechanisms and support you on your journey towards managing your anxiety.

Remember, you deserve to live a life free from constant worry and overthinking. With time and effort, it is possible to find relief from these distressing thoughts.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or guided imagery are some examples of techniques that could potentially reduce the intensity of your symptoms. You might find it beneficial to practice these techniques regularly, even when you're not experiencing an attack, to build up your resilience.

Additionally, it could be worth considering seeking support from a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and assistance. Be patient with yourself as you navigate this process, and know that there is hope for finding relief from your symptoms.

Instead of focusing on external measures of success, try to focus on personal growth and self-acceptance. [Question]
i m not sure if this is the right subreddit to go to but i don t know where else to go my spouse ha struggled with severe depression his whole life it is genetic his dad wa the same any amount of pressure make him worse he constantly feel a though life is not worth living and he s a lost cause he will never feel okay and just want the pain to go away we have a baby coming any day now and i wa worried that pressure wa gon na send him over the edge we have been talking about having him voluntarily go to a psych ward and see if they can help kinda a a last ditch effort before i just give him permission to end it today he talked to his counselor about going to one in a few week after the baby wa here and they came and picked him up an hour later he is pissed doesn t want to be there which i understand is normal he feel completely betrayed by his councellor and never want to go back i m worried that now he is going to pretend like he is fine just to get out the point of this is to get help why won t he just take it i m scared the mental hospital won t help at all i just need you guy who have been there before to be honest with me did it help what thing helped and what made it worse if it doe help or when he come back home what are some thing i can do to continue the healing process or just make his life easier anything else you feel to share please do i hate not knowing thing and this is really killing me right now

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult it is for you to navigate this situation. It's important to remember that your spouse's feelings and reactions are valid, even if they may not seem rational at times. The fact that he is resistant to going to the mental hospital does not necessarily mean that it won't help. It's common for individuals with depression to feel betrayed or resistant to professional help, but it doesn't mean that the help won't be beneficial in the long run.

In terms of what could help, it might be worth exploring different treatment options with your spouse's therapist or psychiatrist. They can provide guidance on medication, therapy techniques, or other interventions that could be effective for him. Additionally, you could encourage open communication between your spouse and his therapist, expressing your concerns and sharing your experiences as a caregiver. This might help your spouse feel more heard and understood.

When he comes back home, it's crucial to create a supportive environment for him. This means being patient, understanding, and non-judgmental. Encourage him to continue his therapy sessions and consider seeking out support groups or community resources that can provide additional assistance. Remember, healing takes time, and it's essential to focus on small steps forward rather than expecting immediate changes.

Lastly, take care of yourself as well. Dealing with a loved one's mental health challenges can be emotionally draining. Make sure to prioritize self-care activities such as exercise, hobbies, spending time with friends, or seeking therapy for yourself if needed.

Please keep in mind that I am not a mental health professional, but I hope these suggestions can provide some guidance and support during this challenging time.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
so i started having suicidal thought in april of last year and they lasted until around november in october i started hanging out with a girl and we started becoming good friend not romantic just friendship my mental health started getting a lot better after a couple month of friendship with her and it s kept getting better ever since a few day ago i made a passive aggressive comment that really upset her she won t text me back now i ve tried apologizing and trying to make thing right with her but i haven t heard back from her i m afraid i ve ruined this friendship forever and now my suicidal thought are back for the first time since last year i always hurt the people that i care about and i hate myself so much that i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you've been experiencing these thoughts and feelings. It takes a lot of courage to reach out for support, and I want you to know that you're not alone in this.

It's great to hear that you've been making progress with your mental health since October, and that your friendship with this girl has been a positive influence for you. However, it's understandable that making a passive aggressive comment may have caused some damage to your relationship with her.

When we hurt the people we care about, it's important to acknowledge our role in the situation and take responsibility for our actions. Apologizing and trying to make things right is a good first step, but it's also important to understand that healing relationships takes time and effort from both parties involved.

Regarding your suicidal thoughts, it's crucial that you reach out to someone you trust, such as a close friend, family member, or even a helpline. These thoughts can be overwhelming, but remember that there are people who care about you and want to help you through this.

Self-hatred is a common feeling when we hurt others, but it's important to remember that our actions don't define our worth as individuals. You deserve love and compassion, just like anyone else. Consider seeking therapy or counseling to explore these feelings and work towards building a healthier mindset.

Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and there are people who care about your well-being. Don't hesitate to reach out for support whenever you need it.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
so i have a mild stutter and i just had an epiphany i ve been letting my stutter control me but i found something amazing out i let my stutter define who i wa a a person instead of an aspect of myself it s so bad that when my parent talk to me like a normal person i d think to myself wow they act like i m normal despite my stutter they see past that and when i would work people would see my name tag and say oh i have a son named my name and i would think he probably doesn t stutter tho i let this define who i wa a a person and i let it really get to me i wa looking at old reddit post from other people asking how people view stutter and most people said they didn t care at all and even found it interesting some even said it wa hot cute made joke sound more natural and a a result more funny not like they found the stutter funny tho and one even said they were turned on by it and someone said something that stuck out to me they pretty much said how you perceive yourself is how others will so if i see myself a weird and anxious i will act that way and be perceived in that way but if i see myself a confident and charismatic and just act like my stutter doesn t bother me and even joke about it then others will perceive me a such this blew my mind a i thought everyone didn t pick up on my stutter at first and just thought i wa super weird but it s just me convincing myself of that so even tho this clicked i still can t just flick the switch off so how do i actually become confident with my stutter it s very mild and is fueled by anxiety so if i can get rid of my anxiety it ll in my opinion make me sound more charismatic and confident so i really wan na figure out how to just own it how do i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult it can be to deal with a stutter and the impact it has on your self-perception and interactions with others. It's great that you've had this epiphany and recognized that you've been allowing your stutter to define who you are as a person.

To become more confident with your stutter, it might be helpful to start by challenging the negative thoughts and beliefs you have about yourself. When you catch yourself thinking that your stutter makes you weird or anxious, try to replace those thoughts with positive affirmations. Remind yourself that your stutter is just a part of you, and it doesn't define your worth as a person.

Another strategy you could try is gradually exposing yourself to situations where you can practice speaking confidently. Start small by practicing in front of a mirror or recording yourself. As you become more comfortable, you can gradually challenge yourself to speak in front of trusted friends or family members. Remember, it's okay to make mistakes and stumble over words. Nobody expects you to be perfect, and they will likely be understanding and supportive.

Additionally, consider seeking out support groups or online communities where you can connect with others who have similar experiences. Sharing your feelings and hearing from others who have overcome their own challenges can provide you with valuable insights and encouragement.

Lastly, if you find that your anxiety is significantly impacting your ability to be confident with your stutter, it may be beneficial to explore therapy options. A mental health professional can work with you to develop personalized strategies and techniques to manage your anxiety and build confidence in your communication skills.

Remember, progress takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate every small step forward. You have the potential to own your stutter and become the confident and charismatic person you aspire to be.

so i ve struggled w executive dysfunction for 9 year throughout my year of college there wa not one assignment that i did not do the night before it wa due i studied late ate terribly amp went thru a terrible depression a year after graduating i still have a really hard time doing thing in general i stall before i do anything at all amp it oftentimes lead to me not doing the thing at all also i kind of live my entire life on pause only taking care of myself when i have something planned or to look forward to i left my job that i wa insanely good at bc the commitment amp longevity terrified me why can t i function amp what ha helped u work thru these feeling

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how challenging it can be to manage executive dysfunction and the emotional impact it has on your daily life. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this struggle, and there are steps you can take to improve your situation.

Firstly, it might be helpful to explore any underlying causes or triggers for your executive dysfunction. Are there specific stressors or situations that tend to exacerbate these symptoms? Identifying these triggers can help you develop coping strategies tailored to your needs.

Additionally, breaking tasks into smaller, manageable steps can make them feel less overwhelming. Prioritizing your responsibilities and setting realistic goals can also be beneficial. Consider using a planner or digital calendar to schedule your tasks and reminders, which can help you stay organized and focused.

Finding ways to incorporate structure and routine into your daily life can also be helpful. This could involve establishing a consistent sleep schedule, regular meal times, and dedicated time for self-care activities. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can also contribute to overall well-being.

While it's understandable that leaving your job was a difficult decision, it's important to remember that finding a new career path or job may not be the only solution. Exploring therapy options, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), could provide you with additional support and guidance in managing your executive dysfunction and associated emotions.

Remember, progress takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories along the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m a frequent poster here i ve struggled all my life with these feeling thing seemed like they were getting better i wa genuinely happy and then it got taken away again i live in shitty section housing i wa kicked out several year ago and i ve been struggling to stay afloat since my mother and i recently discussed me moving back home which wa le than ideal she bought a condo and offered it to me she even suggested i get a roommate i wa overjoyed my so could move in my best friend could move it it seemed wonderful and then once i already signed the paper to move out in two month my mother told me to stop looking for a roommate she ha been considering moving into the larger bedroom and taking my kid sister with her leaving me alone in the smaller bedroom with no support and i have no place to argue against this she bought me a new car a an early birthday gift she s paying for me to go through school i m currently struggling to keep my grade up and she s rightfully angry about it my apartment is messy and she s mad about that too rightfully so i am going to lose my privacy and be stuck in the tiny condo with her without support from my so and my best friend my mother is very controlling so i know i won t be able to play video game or talk to my friend in peace it ll just be lecturing do your homework look for a better job etc etc i don t have the motivation for either i barely have motivation to go to my current job she doesn t get that i m so incredibly depressed and suicidal every single fucking day i just got rejected for a better job and now on top of all that i ll be stuck in a confined space with her with no freedom again and i ll probably become babysitter again for the child i pretty much raised for her it s not fair

[Question]
hi all i m f i ve had very bad anxiety disorder since 0 0 when my uncle passed away the following year i started taking medication and while it help it s not a cure all both my parent passed under different circumstance in october and it s wrecked my emotion i try to do the best i can but sometimes it s just a mess i m out of town right now and i feel so outside of my comfort zone i know i m safe but my stomach is in knot and sorry tmi i haven t left the bathroom much doe anyone have any advice is there anything i can do to calm myself or center myself thank you in advance

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult it is to cope with the loss of loved ones and the anxiety that comes with it. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to help manage your anxiety.

First, it might be helpful to practice deep breathing exercises when you start feeling anxious. Take slow, deep breaths in through your nose, hold for a few seconds, and then exhale slowly through your mouth. This can help activate your body's relaxation response and calm your nervous system.

Additionally, you could try engaging in activities that bring you joy or provide a sense of calm. This could be anything from listening to music, going for a walk in nature, or practicing mindfulness meditation. These activities can help distract your mind from anxious thoughts and bring you back to the present moment.

It's also important to prioritize self-care during this time. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular physical activity. Taking care of your overall well-being can have a positive impact on your mental health.

Lastly, consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member for support. Sometimes just talking about your feelings with someone who cares about you can provide comfort and perspective.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, so it may take some trial and error to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself and know that it's okay to ask for help when you need it.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Additionally, it might be helpful to explore different coping mechanisms that could bring you some relief. For example, engaging in activities that you enjoy or find fulfilling, such as hobbies or creative outlets, could help distract you from negative thoughts and provide a sense of purpose.

When you return from your vacation, it might be beneficial to establish a routine that aligns with your goals and values. [The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how frustrating it can be to deal with anxiety, especially when it interferes with your daily life and relationships. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to manage your anxiety and improve your overall well-being.

First, it might be helpful to explore the root cause of your anxiety. Sometimes, underlying issues such as stress, trauma, or even certain medications can contribute to heightened anxiety levels. Consider keeping a journal to track your thoughts and feelings, which could provide valuable insights into what might be triggering your anxiety.

Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation can help calm your mind and body when anxiety arises. These techniques can be learned through online resources or even apps designed for stress reduction.

It's also important to consider seeking support from loved ones or joining a support group where you can connect with others who may be experiencing similar challenges. Sometimes, simply talking about your anxiety with someone who understands can provide a sense of relief and validation.

Lastly, if your anxiety continues to significantly impact your daily life and relationships, it may be beneficial to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support. They can work with you to develop coping strategies tailored to your specific needs and help you navigate through this difficult time.

Remember, managing anxiety takes time and effort, but with patience and persistence, you can find ways to alleviate your symptoms and improve your overall well-being.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i come from a pretty african evangelical household where mental health wasn t talked about or addressed growing up in the last few year i ve noticed intense wave of sadness and internal pain turn from short stint of time to practically everyday now there will be time period of elation but for the most part my disposition ha remained sad on an almost daily basis i feel anger irritability deep sadness about the way thing haven t worked out for me in the past or currently or intense rejection from others who may not intend their action to be rejection for example the housemate i live with are a married couple who i wa in their wedding so we re all friend when i first moved in they would always have dinner with me asking me what i wanted to eat for dinner but that ha tapered off and tonight i walked in from work late and saw they had dinner together and were enjoying tv it broke me and i went to my room feeling intense inner pain this stuff is so new to me i have no clue how to continue through life because nobody know i struggle with this i don t even know where to begin to share with others or begin to understand what help i need any advice would be much appreciated

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult it is to navigate through these feelings, especially when they've been a part of your daily life for quite some time. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to begin understanding and addressing your emotions.

Firstly, it might be helpful to start by acknowledging and accepting your feelings. It's okay to feel sad, angry, or rejected, and it's okay to feel these emotions deeply. Try not to judge yourself for having these feelings, as they are a natural response to the experiences you've had.

Next, consider reaching out to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member, and sharing what you've been going through. Opening up about your struggles can help alleviate some of the emotional burden you're carrying. Additionally, they may be able to offer support and guidance as you work through your emotions.

You could also explore different coping mechanisms that work for you. This might include engaging in activities that bring you joy or provide a sense of calm, such as listening to music, practicing mindfulness or meditation, journaling, or engaging in hobbies. Finding healthy outlets for your emotions can help you manage them in a constructive way.

It's also worth mentioning that seeking professional help from a mental health therapist could be beneficial for you. A therapist can provide a safe space for you to explore your emotions further, offer guidance tailored to your specific situation, and help you develop strategies to cope with your feelings effectively.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. Be patient with yourself as you navigate through this journey, and know that there is hope for a brighter future ahead.
